page.title: 04A TRAFFIC SURVEY IN BURTON
page.content: Until 1967 traffic in Burton grew so much that the town was nearly brought to a standstill. Then a new by-pass was opened to carry the main A38 away from the town. In a survey of one hourÂ£s traffic on an ordinary working afternoon in 1985 we found the following:- The total number of vehicles was 1700, almost evenly divided between northbound and southbound. There were 780 cars, 730 lorries, 170 vans and 20 buses. The goods carried included building materials, iron/steel, scrap, oil and petrol, food, chemicals, furniture, milk and beer. Building materials were most often carried, with 110 lorries involved, and beer the least, with only three. As Burton is a brewery town, this was surprising. It is very good that these vehicles are no longer clogging the town.
